column5: This article came up on my Google feed, Iâ€™m assuming itâ€™s a real news storyâ€¦..interesting.  https://www.wired2fish.com/news/12-states-to-ban-use-of-livescope-on-state-fisheries

April fools but isnâ€™t there some truth to it? Â  Where is the line?

I have no problem with the gov't managing the resource through seasons, limits, slot sizes, sanctuary zones, number of rods/hooks, barbless, artificials only, etc...but restricting the way in which I can "find" fish...well, that's over the line for me. Regardless, trying to prohibit technology never works.
Letâ€™s ban outboards and trolling motors, they do far more to put fishermen on fish than livescope ever has.

Funny that you mention that, there are a some US states that have banned trail cameras, or cellular trail cameras for hunting.Â  Not that far of a stretch to ban some technology for fishing.Â  I'd be some pissed if they banned ipilot lol.
Canada has banned a very long list of guns for hunting
PMTT has banned it (Professional Muskie Tournament Trail)
Well it isnâ€™t banned , but I for one wouldnâ€™t be happy they are just another tool and it is amazing if one takes the time to learn how to use it

If they actually managed the resource. I think they do a crap job of it as it is all reaction rather than actual planning and management. I had a co make a crappy comment to me this winter about keeping a small lake trout and I told him I just wanted one little guy for breakfast. Then his partner goes on to say that a laker doesn't mature till about 22 inches for reproduction. So whats the point. Do you know what you are talking about or not. Not you crow, him
